awd_titl_txt: The dynamics of embolism formation and  repair in xylem conduits: from bubble scale to loss in plant hydraulic  transport capacity
awd_abstract_narration:
A clear understanding of water usage and resistance to mortality following drought is necessary across tree species. However, despite decades of research, describing plant water movement remains a formidable scientific challenge, and in the absence of this fundamental knowledge, sustainable management of forests will be impossible. All type of plants, including hardwoods and coniferous trees, have core bundles of vascular tissue inside their stems. These circulatory vascular bundles are composed of hollow conduits known as xylem, or wood, that are specialized to transport water efficiently while allowing maximum resistance to drought (hydraulic safety). Sufficient water transport in plants is not guaranteed when water demand increases during hot and dry days. Under those conditions, water in wood becomes highly unstable and trees can die once an air bubble enters and spreads inside those hollow cells. By integrating modelling activities with visual and physiological processes related to air entry and air bubble formation in wood, plant water transport and resistance to drought will be established. The primary impacts of the proposed project will be to advance discovery in the field of water relations and hydraulic architecture of vascular plants by predicting tree mortality following drought, while promoting training for the next generation of scientists and educators. Results from this research can be directly used in future predictions of vegetation responses to climate. The findings here will also be of interest to policy makers, plant breeders and land managers concerned with potential drought impacts on productivity and distributions of certain species.

The overall objective of this project is to link the dynamics of embolism formation and removal under tension in xylem of woody plants starting from the bubble scale and integrating the resulting dynamics along individual conduits to arrive at whole-plant vulnerability to cavitation curves. The specific objectives are to 1) measure and model the timescale required for the gas phase induced by cavitation to fully embolize an entire xylem conduit; 2) investigate the conditions under which bubble formation can spread from one conduit to another; 3) investigate the possibility of bubble resorption under tension to occur; and 4) determine the relation between embolism formation and loss of hydraulic conductivity. To achieve the project objectives, a series of science questions will be addressed: Research question 1 (bubble scale): what are the mechanisms and dynamics of embolism formation and removal in a single xylem conduit? What is the time required for a gas bubble to completely fill and to drain a conduit for varying conduit structures and xylem tensions? Research question 2 (conduit connectivity): Is the time needed for the embolism to fill a conduit dependent on conduit size, and the rigidity of the end-wall pit membrane? Research question 3 (Up-scaling to whole-plant): Do the dynamics of bubble formation in a single conduit explain the whole organ vulnerability to embolism curves. The formulation of bubble formation and spread in transpiring plants will represent a major step forward as the theoretical computational methods, and experimental techniques are now ripe for making this progress.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual Merit of the project was to advance discovery in the field of water relations and hydraulic architecture of vascular plants, while promoting training for the next generation of scientists and educators. This project effectively integrated research at different levels of organization from cellular to whole plant by merging experiments, theory, and simulations. The knowledge gained allowed a comprehensive perspective to be formulated that addresses many aspects of plant water storage and resistance to drought.

Water inside plants forms a continuous chain from water in soils to the water evaporating from leaf surfaces. Failures in this chain result in reduced transpiration and photosynthesis and are caused by soil drying and/or cavitation‐induced xylem embolism. This NSF project help determined why variations in xylem network characteristics (such as conduit connectivity) explained trends among woody species, like the ‘safety-efficiency’ trade-off hypothesis. The findings also highlight the picture of the xylem as a complex and delicate conductive system whose hydraulic behaviour transcends a passive gradient-based flow. Finally, these insights provide a better understanding of the existing coordination between the biophysical structure of wood, plant growth, hydraulic partitioning, and physiological plant functions. Although generally overlooked, mechanistic and probabilistic links between vessel anatomical traits and inter-vessel connections were found to be major determinants of vulnerability to drought curve shape and plant resistance to water stress.

Xylem embolism and plant hydraulic failure share several analogies to ‘catastrophe theory’ in dynamical systems. These catastrophes are often represented in the physiological and ecological literature as tipping points when control variables exogenous (e.g., soil water potential) or endogenous (e.g., leaf water potential) to the plant are allowed to vary on time scales much longer than time scales associated with cavitation events. Through this proposal, plant hydraulics viewed from the perspective of catastrophes at multiple spatial scales was considered with attention to bubble expansion within a xylem conduit, organ‐scale vulnerability to embolism, and whole‐plant biomass as a proxy for transpiration and hydraulic function. The hydraulic safety‐efficiency tradeoff, hydraulic segmentation and maximum plant transpiration were examined using this framework. Underlying mechanisms for hydraulic failure at fine scales such as cell wall structure and cell‐wall mechanics, intermediate scales such as xylem network properties and at larger scales such as soil–tree hydraulic pathways were discussed.

The primary impacts of the proposed project was to advance discovery in the field of water relations and hydraulic architecture of vascular plants, while promoting training for the next generation of scientists and educators. The knowledge gained will allow a comprehensive perspective to be formulated that addresses many aspects of plant resistance to drought. This project effectively integrated research at different levels of organization from cellular to whole plant by merging experiments, theory, and simulations. The formulation of bubble formation and spread in transpiring plants represented a major step forward as the theoretical tactics, computational methods, and experimental techniques were ripe for making this progress. Finally, the findings here are also of interest to policy makers and land managers concerned with potential drought impacts on productivity and distributions of certain species. They are also  of interest to tree and plant breeders involved in identifying traits associated with survival and adequate productivity within a given environment. 

From this project research, three broader impacts connected global plant functioning to citizen-observable local phenomena through: (1) Engagement of undergraduate and high school students and teachers from North Carolina in cutting-edge research (2) Mentoring three graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow in interdisciplinary research, and (3) Broadening participation among students underrepresented in STEM fields. 

In addition, the ideas contained within and the data generated from this project were disseminated through (a) formal seminars at Duke University and the University of Georgia, (b) national and international meetings, (c) over 50 peer-reviewed journals, and (d) the public deposition of hydraulic trait measurements on the  Xylem database and the SAPFLUXNET network.. The broader impacts also lied in the development of mechanistic mathematical models that identified future vulnerabilities of water resources resulting from pine plantation expansion. Results from this research can be directly used in future predictions of vegetation responses to climate change because hydraulic characteristics and their impact on carbon gain and survival is likely a primary determinant of species distributions. Finally, the results also provide guidance for the risk assessment of environment given the strong objectivity of catastrophe theory compared with other evaluation methods. The time is ripe for this undertaking given (i) the proliferation of remote sensing products (NDVI for plants, SMAPS for near‐surface soil moisture, ECOSTRESS for estimating canopy transpiration), (ii) the availability of accessible past, present and projections of large‐scale hydrocli-matic variables (e.g., air temperature and precipitation), and (iii) a wealth of experiments and global public data bases on plant water use (SAPFLUXNET) and hydraulics traits across biomes and species (TRY database and Xylem Functional Trait database).
